reviews.review_text: Bioshock + quantum mechanics + Wolfenstein: the new order + Dead Space + Half-Life 2 + Resistance + Time travel - Hitler + Stalin  Can't believe I've never played this before

Singularity is clearly inspired by Bioshock. Not as good though, however it is still a good addition to the genre and the use of time altering mechanics is very interesting. It's heavily scripted though and every level has tons of health packs and ammo scattered around - no a fan of that. Also, it feels as if the devs used Google translate for all the Russian in this game. The story was interesting at first, but by the time you get to the end and try to understand the whole plot, you'll remember Bruce Willis from that diner scene in 'Looper'. It's one of those time travelling stories where they make you intentionally confused. You went back in time because your future self made you go back in time - talking about a loop hole.        Trying to understand the plot of this game ...

To say that Singularity wears its inspiration on its sleeve is to put it very lightly. The game is almost shamelessly derivative, taking the both the style and character building of BioShock, the gravity gun from Half-Life 2, and throwing in a few nods to F.E.A.R. However, this mish-mash of other games' ideas is by no means a bad thing. If anything, Singularity manages to almost play as a 'best of' collection of FPS trappings, the ultimate compilation of cool gimmicks and toys seen in the genre over the past five years.

It's a shooter so no complicated reviews.  Pros: -You shoot thingies with your badass guns. -Cool ideas with time warping (that's a pro) but instead of shooting thingies with it, it's given as a gimmick to solve some really ♥♥♥♥ing stupid puzzles. (that's a con) -Good atmosphere and graphics. -Hilariously bad Russian translations -Good guns for every taste. -Lots of gore and death animations -Non-scripted leaping attacks by zombie enemies that are not QTES and you actually have to aim to push them off (Wow they just don't make that anymore) -Shoot off hands and legs of the enemies and actually feel satisfied. -Multiplayer is really fun but dead, sadly. -Manipulate time with a deployable force field and shoot bullets, throw knives (or whatever you've got there) at your enemies and laugh at their faces when the time flows again. -You can get creative with your kills or play as you want. -There's this boss fight.  Cons: -Not enough thingies to shoot sometimes. -Too easy even on hard difficulty. -Story is bad. (or mediocre at best) -Some perks are out of place, costs too much or either totally useless (Why not give them outright?) -Really stupid puzzles that are too easy, why puzzles instead of more thingies to shoot? -Short (Thanks to stupid puzzles.) -Final level is a dissapointment -ONLY 2 NINJA ZOMBIE FIGHTS? FOR REAL?????? They should be regular enemies. -Really low replayability(Though i played it 2 times, but that's just me), pretty linear. Also illusion of choice  This game just cries for overhaul, but all in all, Raven software delivered a pretty decent shooter with a twist, like always. I'll give it a 7

One of the most enjoyable shooters I've played in years! Half-Life meets Bioshock meets Timesplitters: Future Perfect meets F.E.A.R meets C&C Red Alert meets Wolfenstein meets Timeshift meets Lost. The result isn't terribly original, but it's amazingly fun.  The game constantly surprises with a change in gameplay and mood every 15 minutes. Unlike Duke Nukem Forever, it actually does a good job of blending 'old skool' gameplay with modern game design.  Pro tip 1: weapon lockers allow you to swap weapons, not just upgrade them. Pro tip 2: the upgrades for the 'Deadlock' time-freezing bubble are incredibly overpowered and yet suprisingly cheap, so unless you want to make the game very easy, don't upgrade Deadlock, or at most only upgrade it once. Pro tip 3: if you have Windows 7 and the audio seems quiet, one solution is to Alt Tab out of the game, go into your volume controls, find the entry for SIngularity and boost the volulme.

Singularity is a visually engaging fps that does not try anything new. The game is a good length, has a solid story, a hand-full of strong characters and a nice variety of combat. The game undoubtedly feels like a side project but a finished one! It might not have the detail and love that one would expect in a CoD game, but I was impressed with Activision's ability to begin and end a story with the time that was given.  The game takes many ques from other games. While Singularity might not bring anything new to the table, it does bring a well blended action fps for any gamer to enjoy. Nothing is taken too far with this game. There is a good number of different enemy types, but not so many that the player isn't able to learn how to combat them before the game is over. Also, there are at least ten weapons to choose from -- most of which can be upgraded and changed out at weapon stations.  The 'TMD' device that the player is given adds a shocking amount of combat options. The different uses of weapons and 'TMD' abilities with the added upgrading and leveling system could make for another good play-though -- maybe two. Unfortunately, the fights are scripted, and that takes a bit from the replays.  Over all, the game gets a good review because it feels 'humble.' It isn't a ground breaking or epic title, and it does not try to be. The game gives the player a gripping intro, good progression and good old fashioned boss fights!   Note: $30 would have been spot on the day this game came out. Best bought on sale now.         Singularity

You get used to just fighting baddies with guns, and then suddenly you are thrown back into the island after everything went to crap, and you have to remember that terrible things can pop out at you again.

Surprisingly good. Although you breeze through it in 5 hours and it's not very hard (unbalanced even - if you use the time slowdown sphere and some tmp upgrades you can just run through most parts). It starts off quite weak but once you get a hold of the TMP it gets really good. The story is rather straightforward but I have to say that I really enjoyed it and it was refreshing to play a linear FPS that was this entertaining.  Singularity really resembles half life in quite a few ways and it is really good in teaching you the mechanics. The controls are also really intuitive/good (except the default bind for healing)   my issues: One note on mechanical side - I lost a lot of E99 money because in tmp you actually have to equip something to the slot. I missed that and treated it as other upgrades so I had a ton of upgrades for tmp that did not work and I spent the currency for.  The lore is expanded via notes and tapes but there could be more of the 'show, don't tell' visual narrative.  Overall it seemed like there was more potential than what the game showed and the puzzles could include more variations (i,e, you need to use the grenade launcher exactly once and then forget about it, modifying time in later sections is mostly used for opening boxes and restoring tape recorders compared to strong first half where it was used for various objects, turning soldiers into husks was fun but rather inefficient shortly after it was introduced etc).

Katorga-12. Nevar 4get ;_;  In all honesty though, this is a 'Hidden Gem' game if ever I've played one. A great selection of unique and fun weapons that all have weight to them (dat sniper rifle), a great gore/gib system, frantic combat with competent AI, a half way decent story, and unique time bending abilites that give you the edge you need in combat. Words can't describe how fun it is to put a squad of 4 or more enemies into a stasis bubble, walking into the bubble, taking aim and firing a bullet right between each enemies eyes, then collapsing the bubble and watching all 4 mean go flying backwards as their brains leak out the back of their foreheads. Or dropping a grenade at their feet and watching them explode inside the stasis bubble in super slow motion. Good times. And in the end game, when you get your final upgrade, you're literally a god amongst men.   This game represents what Activision COULD have given us- fun, unique, and well designed shooters, that encouraged fun over realism, weapons that all had unique functions instead of 'This rifle shoots really fast, this one shoots in 3 round bursts, and this one fire slowly but deal lots of damage.'   Instead we're stuck with a new Cawwa Doody every year. Our sins our great, and we gotta carry that weight. No amount of rewinding time will fix this now.

Short Answer   Should you buy it - $30 is a little bit much for a four year old game but it is a good game and if you really like FPS's, Yes Should you buy it on sale - Absolutely   Long Answer   Singularity is a standard FPS with just a little bit more that sets it above the norm.  Visuals : The visuals in the game wont destroy your graphics card or anything but it does tax it a little bit. The scenery and set pieces look very nice, sometimes really pretty. There is no reuse of areas that I can tell ( aka same corridor syndrome ) and you will get a good feeling of progression ( you can visually see getting closer to your goal). The enemies look nice but dont change much in the looks area but at least you dont get the same guy but his time hes red! Overall - Good looking game that helps to visually immerse you into the world.  Story and Setting : (Spoiler Free) The setting is an Island off the coast of Russia that has some dirty little secrets and as a US special forces soldier you have to infiltrate the island and find out what is going on. As a base story it is just like most of the other FPS games out there but Singularity adds a nice twist on the basic formula that makes it feel new and refreshing. Overall - The story wont break the bank on amazing plots but it will engage you very well and help to keep you playing to find out what happens next.  Gameplay : This is were the game really sets itself above a normal FPS. It has a slight rpg feel with upgradeable weapons and skill selecting although neither is a game changer or breaker. It has good gun play and the powers that you use are fun and work well but what this game does really well is that it lets you play the way you want to. No, there is no stealth or anything like that, it is all action and if something is in your way it has to die but the game gives you incredible freedom on how it dies. You can play and complete this entire game with nothing but guns or once you get your powers you can complete the entire game with those. It never limits you and it gives you plenty of ammo or easily throwable items no matter which way you want to play. Overall - The gameplay is great and gives you a great feel of freedom that never tells you how you should play it   Replayability : While the story does give this game a little bit of replay ( you might want to play again just to see all the clues you didnt understand in the first playthrough ) and the gameplay lets you play it again in differnet ways, there is really no reason to play it more than a few times.  Personal overall enjoyment - This game was a good change of pace to me for normal FPS's. I enjoyed playing the game and was glad of the purchase I made. I will probably play it again sometime down the line and have no problem recommending it as a good game.

Also, I can honestly say that I haven't had as much fun playing a weapon any game as I have playing with the Seeker. Seriously, that weapon is some fun ♥♥♥♥.

When this game was released i thought nothing of it mostly because it came out when the plague of sub par fps games started. I only decided to try this game once i saw it on a top 10 hidden gems countdown. I did enjoy my time with the game but i do have a few problems with it that may ruin the game for some people. For starters the game is a measly 5 hours long with little replay value. Yes the game dose have multiple endings but the game saves your progress right before your chose what ending you will get. My next problem is the difficulty. The game in my opinion was way to easy. The tmd made combat interesting but it also made you unstoppable. And the amount of medkits you get are insane. there were many times where i would pass up on 5 in one room because i was maxed out. I only died once and stood there and let 5 monsters chomp on me while i spun around. The few bosses that are there honestly just feel like normal enemies with giant ♥♥♥♥ me blisters on them. The only thing that stuck out in my mind was the weapon selection. you have your basics like a revolver, assault rifle, shotgun, and sniper rifle. But then you start getting guns like the spikeshot that is a railgun with a delay or a grenade launcher that has grenades that you can move on your own. However you are limited to two guns that you can carry except for super weapons. I went through most of the game with the assault rife as my primary for most of the game. and if the is a situation where you can use a gun to its fullest there is convinently a dead body with on laying right in front of you. The super weapons bring the most flavor to the table. The seeker fires an explosive round that you can control in a cool bullet time scene. And then there is a rocket launcher. Ok they may have run out of ideas at that point. The game is fun however and if you looking to kill some time (no pun intended) i recommend picking this game up only on a sale though.

Singularity is a fantastic singleplayer FPS. The setting is an abandoned Russian facility that did experiments on a mysterious substance that affects time. That's the gameplay hook, you explore by dilating time and the age of objects around you. You can make enemies decay right in front of you. It's a fun experience.  Unfortunate for the developer Raven, Activision sent this solid gem to die at retail with no advertising support and so the game was religated to obscurity. I'm sure the multiplayer is dead at this point but the singleplayer alone is worth the price of admission.

Alternative history games I feel generally fall into two categories; absurdly grim alterno-dramas that take themselves too serviously, and the nonsensical cheese fests that know its a silly parody. Its a premise that can go both ways in quality. Singularity treads a good balance in melodrama and campiness, and offers up a decent shooter.  Story is your standard Cold War 'what would happened if'. 1950's Russians discover an all powerful, time distorting element E99 (not to be confused with Einsteinium) on a remote island, experiments go horribly wrong and left to stew for fifty years, and a botched American black ops mission changes the timeline and basically gives Russia the world, and you have to jump back and forth to fix the present/future. There have been better plots in games, but this isn't a totally laughable B movie. It is forunate that the games atmosphere saves it from B movie hilarity. Being trapped inside a decaying, direlict research complex greatly enhances the overall mood and plot of Singulariy, adding a mounting sense of dread and horror that; at least for me, was almost too much to handle.  Singularity's gameplay is pretty competent; starting off as your traditional FPS with generous doses of action survivor horror thrown in for good measure. It shortly becomes what I can only discribe as a 50's sci fi shooter with the introduction of the Time Manipulation Device, a powerful wristband that let you age and revert certain objects and enemies at will, it is perhaps not as solid as Half Life's Gravity Gun. But its still pretty fun. The guns you find throughout are varied and not half bad, but as you find your formula to fight Mutants and Russian soldiers, you'll find yourself using and upgrading only a combination of three or four for everything. Finally there is a lot of variety to them, some of them are not the smartest AI's I've seen; But some, like the mutants that shift in and out of the material world, are unnervingly tough to deal with.  Singularity is a little rough around the edges, but at the end of day its a very satisifing shooter. It does a worthly job of blending its story, atmosphere and game mechanics into something I found memorable and be more willing to replay some day. And in an Era of throw away military shooters, that is saying something.

This is without a doubt one if the best games I have played in years, though it has some 'quirks' that are typical to ported games.  The good The story is extremely well done, with excellent voice acting and animation. Combat is fluid and frantic but is not constant nor does it swamp all other aspects of the game. There are plenty of moments to just look around and feel the atmosphere of the game which really allows for deep immersion. The slower moments in the game are dotted with some very good and logical puzzles that you must solve to advance or solve to reach a hidden area. The absolute best part of the game is the blend of visual and audio aspects to put you into the most tense condition that I can recall while playing any game. Though it does have the thrice cursed 'Boss Monsters' It includes them in such a fluid manner and rather than just throwing you into an arena with a monster that you have no clue what the 'super secret' way to defeat it could be, you are given hints along the way that alllow you to make quick tactical assessments and fight the creatures without wasting your time or ammo searching for the special spots to poke at. Bravo design team!! This is the only game that I actually enjoyed fighting the boss monsters. Not that is was easy.  now the bad; The number one most terrible thing about this game is that it is absolutley too short, in 19 hours I finished it twice. granted I tend to finish game more quickly than most, but with a story this good I would have loved to stay in it a while longer. There are a few places that the collision actually blocks the path you are suppsed to follow in such a way as to make you think it is another invisible wall. Here i would like to note that I HATE invisible walls!! When you make a barrier it should look like a barrier not like an open path that might lead to a hidden area. The controls suffer from being ported over from a game deck so they do not really mesh well with keyboard and mouse but it is not too bad and you can remap them to more fit you preferences which helps a lot. There are several places in the tutorial section of the game that gloss over some things that you really need to know so it's very easy to miss which makes using the equipment later in game more difficult than it should.  Over all this is a beautiful gem of a game that I think anyone who is a fan of tense and dark gameplay should absolutely pick up, and tell their friends

Singularity, a 2008 release developed by Raven Software and published by Activision, is a good example of a game made with no intent other than to ‘follow the leader’: while the game incorporates gameplay ideas with some potential, it suffers from an incredibly flimsy plot and disconnected design choices.  Let’s start with the positives: some of the weapons, like the Seeker and the Dethex Launcher, offer some creative opportunities in combat, and combined with the TMD, combat gameplay almost never becomes a chore, which is good since it’s pretty much 95% of the game.  That’s where the positives end, though: the game lacks any creative thought outside of combat. For example, the TMD is a pretty see-through attempt at combining the Plasmids from BioShock and the Gravity Gun from Half-Life 2, with a gimmick that just adds one extra button press to crate-stacking sequences. The art design feels like a poorly made Soviet AU of Rapture, and the voice acting makes Hollywood Russian accents sound genuine.  The plot is the worst part of the game: I understand, time travel isn’t exactly an easy trope to work with. But even taking that into account, the story is horrendously full of plot holes, and is little more than a barely-connected series of events to get you from setpiece A to setpiece B through combat arena C.  Overall, I’d say: if you happen to own the game, give it a spin to play around with the combat mechanics, but don’t bother throwing away any money on it if you want a satisfying game experience.

I didn't expect much, but I was surprised to find a ton of cool game mechanics. The ability to selective age objects, create time warp felds, slow down time when scoping, and use telekinesis opened up a lot of cool gameplay doors. These aren't, perhaps, new features - other games have tried it out before. But this game makes an effort to let you interact with tons of environmental objects, which is nice - it turned an otherwise standard shooter experience into something that felt pretty interactive.  But the game's flaws outrank the fun. In order to get the sound to work, you need to disable any recording devices in Windows. The sensitivity bar won't allow you to go lower than a certain amount (which is still way too high), so instead of trying to find a config file, I just halved the DPI on my mouse. The FOV is artifically low (we're talking probably 65, here) so you get a claustrophobic sense of the world.  I might have been able to forgive these shortcomings (and I did, for a few hours), but the real killer was the unbalanced gameplay. I handled giant mutants, blinking mutants, hordes of russians, and twisted undead with no problem. But at a specific point in the game, you're placed into the position of dealing with enemies who kill you in 2-3 shots, and which you're unable to really fight back against. The swarm of suicide bugs who, with three different hits, will kill you. The blade-armed assassin mutant who could take a literal dozen sniper shots to the head (!!) without being visibly damaged. These encounters took about half an hour to get past (a long time to spend in one encounter), with lots of frustration. And worst, they're surrounded by other no-problem encounters. I had thought to crank down the difficulty and cheese my way through these speedbumps, but you can't even do that.  Add that to the game's general low-res appearance, uninteresting environments (someone said it was all brown - that's true), and unsatisfying sound; and the result was that I simply couldn't find a reason to continue playing.

You know those games that create a unique, compelling, immersive world? This is not one of those games.  This game reminded me strongly of the Russian-created game, 'You Are Empty,' which also sends you through a destroyed world created by Soviet super-science gone horribly awry - AND involves time travel. One detail - 'You Are Empty' came out in 2007. Hmm. Funny, that.  Anyway, though 'You are Empty' feels like a game created by a small indie studio, the super-Soviet world they created felt more authentic than the one in Singularity, created by big studio Raven Software.  I am still playing it, but my biggest pet peeve so far is when they have English text with silly things like backwards 'R's, I suppose to make it seem Russian.  Anyway, the gameplay is reasonable, though not particularly inspired, so if you get it cheap enough, and you aren't expecting much, you should have some fun. My 'thumbs down' is based on the current price of $29.99.

Couldn't get into it. Singularity has a lot of interesting ideas, but takes advantage of none of them. The game's big gimmick, the TMD, is nothing more than a contextual extra 'use' key. While it has other abilities to use against enemies, none of them I encountered were entirely necessary to use. This is mostly because the game's assault rifle is the greatest weapon ever created in the history gaming. With plentiful ammo, high accuracy, low recoil, and able to take out most common enemies with one headshot, there is no real reason to use any other weapon. It's effectiveness causes the novelty of the games 'unique' weapons to wear off very fast. Sure, you can use the gun that allows you to guide bullets into enemies around cover, or slightly out of your line of sight. But in the time it takes for you to guide that bullet into a single enemy, you can kill that same enemy and his 5 comrades, and the rest of his reinforcements in the same amount of time with that godlike assault rifle. There is nothing else to the gunplay, just shoot them in the face with the AR and gg. You can't even throw grenades. You'll find more depth in a CoD game, which is an impressive feat I must admit.  Beyond the boring gunplay there is not much else of merit. The story suffers the same logical inconsistencies of any story involving time travel. My favorite part was going back in time to stop the evil Russian general from killing the good scientist, and after bursting into the room, unloading 10+ bullets into his face and blasting him through the window several stories above the ground, he ends up surviving and going on to rule the world. ♥♥♥♥in Russians man. The characters are dull cliches ripped off from other, better games. The evil general, the good scientist, and the random woman helping you are basically the Russian copies of Dr. Breen, Dr. Kleiner, and Alyx from HL2. There's also the incredibly generic soldier buddy that you'll find by the dozens in any CoD game. You spend about the first 30 minutes of the game with him until he gets shot in the face by the general because he's a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing moron. This of course is after you get randomly sent back in time and accidentally save the general because you're a stupid ♥♥♥♥ing moron as well. The only interesting attribute of any of them was the well modelled ♥♥♥ of the woman, but I digress...  Overall, Singularity is an incredibly bland shooter with some well conceptualized yet poorly executed ideas. If you absolutely must try it however, or you think I'm full of ♥♥♥♥, at the very least wait to buy it when it's on sale for $5 or less.
